questions.question_text: A new vulnerability enables a type of malware that allows the unauthorized movement of data from a system. Which of the following would detect this behavior?

A systems administrator is auditing all company servers to ensure they meet the minimum security baseline. While auditing a Linux server, the systems administrator observes the /etc/shadow file has permissions beyond the baseline recommendation. Which of the following commands should the systems administrator use to resolve this issue?

discussion.content: Passed my exam today friends, this Q was on there, I chose A. Also, all the PBQs were there as well.

comments.content: How did you find it ? Do you think its better to focus from Q 600 onwards?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The chmod, or change mode, command allows an administrator to set or modify a file's permissions. Every UNIX/Linux file has an owner user and an owner group attached to it, and every file has permissions associated with it.

Selected Answer: A
Sudo chmod 69420
im going with the chmod command

Selected Answer: A
he should modify the permission using Psudo chmod as i know

questions.question_text:
A security team received the following requirements for a new BYOD program that will allow employees to use personal smartphones to access business email:

â€¢ Sensitive customer data must be safeguarded.
â€¢ Documents from managed sources should not be opened in unmanaged destinations.
â€¢ Sharing of managed documents must be disabled.
â€¢ Employees should not be able to download emailed images to their devices.
â€¢ Personal photos and contact lists must be kept private.
â€¢ IT must be able to remove data from lost/stolen devices or when an employee no longer works for the company.

Which of the following are the best features to enable to meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: EG
Because this Q says BYOD, I can't choose remote wipe - containerization should still be able to wipe only the company info (messer notes), and I would select geofencing for stopping the sharing in unmanaged locations, so I picked EG

Selected Answer: EG
I'm stuck on the bullet, "Documents from managed sources should not be opened in unmanaged destinations". Making me select Geofencing. With containerization, wouldn't you be able to remove the container to get rid of data, making you not need the remote wipe feature?

Selected Answer: AG
Remote Wipe for all of your "getting rid of data" needs. Also to include the "separation of duties" checkbox.

Containerization for the security and keeping things private that need to be and putting things in the managed box and the un-managed box.

Selected Answer: AG
Remote wipe
Containerization

Selected Answer: AG
Remote wipe to wipe.
Containerization - fulfills all the other needs.

One issue with the suggested answer is that it does not address bullet point #2 (you need geofencing to address it!)
the other problem is Remote Wipe, wipes the ENTIRE phone, including personal data, whereas containerization can have it's container only wiped.
Alas, for the exam, common sense, once again, will not prevail, so A & G are the answers regardless

Selected Answer: AG
Remote wipe will allow the admins to delete the data if the device is lost or stolen.
Containerization will allow isolation of the sensitive corporate emails and other applications that the employees are downloading to their devices, while keeping users data separate.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AG
G. Containerization: Containerization involves creating a separate and secure container or workspace on the device for business applications and data. This allows for the isolation of business data from personal data and enables better control over the business-related activities on the device.

A. Remote wipe: Remote wipe is a crucial security feature that allows the IT team to remotely erase all data on a lost or stolen device. This helps in safeguarding sensitive customer data and ensuring that company information does not fall into the wrong hands

Selected Answer: AG
I feel like we should choose Geofencing too as it helps with the "unknown locations" key word

Selected Answer: AG
Feels like there are should be more options to choose from to cover all the requirements but out of what we have I think it's remote wipe and containers

Selected Answer: AG
Remote wipe and Containerization

questions.question_text: Which of the following security controls is used to isolate a section of the network and its externally available resources from the internal corporate network in order to reduce the number of possible attacks?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
It's B, they use Air Gapping to separate things that shouldn't be on a network or facing towards the inter-webz. Solely for security reasons since these machines/devices usually don't get updated often/new versions come out of the devices. So Air Gapping comes into play to literally isolate it and have it safe from any kind of attackers. Stuff like this would be SCADA factory equipment, camera systems, or even embedded systems sometimes too. To get to these, you most definitely have to be inside the building physically to get ahold of the equipment if you're not already a part of the company that has the Air Gapped "network." 
sorry for the long winded speech.

Selected Answer: B
It's air gap: is a security measure that physically isolates a computer or network from external networks, making it inaccessible via any network connection.
Vaulting is a thing but used to securely storing sensitive data in a protected location, can be names cyber vault or just vault.

Selected Answer: B
B. Air gap

They are all wrong.
But air gap is the least wrong.

Selected Answer: B
An air gap is a security measure that physically isolates a secure network or computer system from unsecured networks, such as the internet or less secure internal networks.

comments.content: It is, but it's referred to an isolated copy of data, not a network or a computer

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Vaulting is not a thing lol

Selected Answer: B
Air gapping
These new questions are just added. Anyone know why? are from 701 exam?

Selected Answer: B
I am comfortable with B as the answer

Selected Answer: A
Air gap is a security measure that physically or logically isolates a computer, network, or system from unsecured networks, such as the internet or other parts of an internal network.

questions.question_text: A security analyst is responding to a malware incident at a company. The malware connects to a command-and-control server on the internet in order to function. Which of the following should the security analyst implement first?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Adding a IP based firewall rule is a lot quicker then looking at the network structure to modify it. B , first you add a quick firewall rule to block the malicious command and control IP then you make network segmentation changes for future proofing

Selected Answer: A
A. Network segmentation

comments.content: A is definitely a step but after B.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Network segmentation IS NOT the same as containment OR isolation. It isn't a defense tactic, it's a network architecture setup for a performance boost amongst other things, but it isn't isolation from the rest of the network.

In the context of CompTIA, "segment" and "containment" might refer to different concepts. "Segment" could relate to dividing networks for security or organizational purposes, while "containment" often refers to isolating threats within a network to prevent their spread. They're related but not necessarily synonymous.

Yes, from ChatGPT.. but weâ€™re confusing segmentation and containment I think. Segmentation, containment and isolation all have different meaning when refers g to CompTIA.. confusing I know.

Selected Answer: A
Also see Q661 and 677. It takes more time to create new IP firewall rules that should be done after containment. Or eradication.

Selected Answer: B
b is better

Selected Answer: B
in order to stop the attack you first need to B. implement firewall rules. After that you can A. segment the network to make it even more harder to access command and control.

Selected Answer: B
Implementing IP-based firewall rules can immediately help block traffic to and from known malicious IP addresses associated with the command-and-control servers. This action effectively cuts off the malware's ability to receive commands or exfiltrate data, thus containing the infection.

Selected Answer: B
The question explained that it is connecting to a command and control. If the question was asking how would you stop the spread on the network it'd be A but since the emphasis was on the command and control it's B

Selected Answer: A
what this guy said: Mizzcoors

Selected Answer: B
The most effective and immediate action to take in this scenario is B. IP-based firewall rules. By quickly implementing firewall rules to block the known IP addresses of the C&C server, the security analyst can effectively stop the malware from communicating with its external controllers, thus mitigating the threat. This action directly addresses the most urgent need: stopping the malware's active threat to the network.

B - You can verify in Professor Messers class on bots. Link is below along with the last sentence

"You can often identify an active infection by scanning an on-demand anti-malware scan and watching the network for any unusual traffic patterns. And if you know the type of network flows that will be used for the command and control, you can block that at the firewall or with an IPS or firewall at the workstation level."

https://www.professormesser.com/security-plus/sy0-601/sy0-601-video/bots-and-botnets-2/

Selected Answer: A
If we follow the Incident Response Process:
1) Preparation - hardening
2) Identification - detection
3) Containment :)
4) Eradication
5) Recovery
6) Lesson Learned
Performing containment involves isolating or segregating the affected servers and resources to prevent further unauthorized access or data exfiltration. 
This can be done by disconnecting the compromised systems from the network, disabling their access to sensitive data or critical resources, or implementing network segmentation to isolate the affected parts of the infrastructure.
Setup DNS sinkhole by setting ip-based firewall rules to locate the infected machines.

Selected Answer: A
Containment comes first. Then you deal with blocking the IPs, etc.

Selected Answer: A
After an incident is identified, containment is the first step. CompTIA defines containment as either isolation-based or segmentation-based:

Isolation-based containment is "making sure that there is no longer an interface between the affected component and your production network or the Internet." (Section 17C). Segmentation-based containment is specifically mentioned as being a tactic against an established C&C channel. "As opposed to completely isolating the hosts, you might configure the protected segment as a sinkhole or honeynet and allow the attacker to continue to receive filtered (and possibly modified) output over the C&C channel to deceive him or her into thinking the attack is progressing successfully." (Section 17C).

I don't believe any of the answer choices besides Network Segmentation (A) allows for containment of the incident. IP-based firewall rules and content filters are undoubtedly configuration changes to be implemented to prevent future/ongoing communication , they would not take priority over containment.

comments.content: I have to agree with you. The incident response plan says preparation, identification, containment, eradication, lessons learned -- thus network segmentation is under containement and the Ip firewall rules would fall after that -- in the eradication of future instances

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Block malicious IP first

The security analyst should FIRST implement containment. Once you've identified the systems/hosts that are infected, please ISOLATE them via Network Segmentation.
Thereafter, you can start battling with other forms of remediation.

Selected Answer: B
B. IP-based firewall rules
D. Content filler.

Both B and D are correct. 
You can accomplish this with either IP firewall rules or content filters. 

I'm just guessing that IP firewall rules is "more" correct.

Selected Answer: B
First you need block ip

B. IP-based firewall rules

When responding to a malware incident where the malware connects to a command-and-control server on the internet, the first step a security analyst should implement is IP-based firewall rules.
From the book: "content filter can help prevent malware from phoning home or connecting to C2 sites and it can also prevent users from responding to phishing attacks and similar sites"

Selected Answer: D
The IP can be changed from a pool of IPs so no. best answer here is D

Selected Answer: A
Network Segmentation

Selected Answer: B
Firewall rules do the job.
